1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (A)
S. D. Warren's accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach. It integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  Our prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) found in the 40 CFR-68, Prevention Program.
1.1.1.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (A)(1)
S. D. Warren has a management system in place which oversees the implementation and ongoing use of the RMP elements.  The Managing Director is responsible for RMP implementation.  This program, along with other mill policies, eliminates and /or reduces the likelihood and consequences of a hazardous chemical release.
1.1.2.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3  (A)(2)
S. D. Warren maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  The program is based on the EPA's Program Level 3 elements.  The RMP elements have been combined with like elements of the mill's OSHA PSM program. 
1.2.    S. D. WARREN STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLING AT THE MUSKEGON, MICHIGAN SITE (b)
The mill employs approximately 258 full-time employees (including all medical or other laid off employees), some of whom operate the covered processes.  Today, bulk chlorine in one ton containers is only used as part of the water production operations.
1.2.1.    SITE DESCRIPTION (b)(1)
The facility has chlorine storage at one location.  Chlorine from this system is used in the mill's water treatment plant. 
The water treatment plant's only source of chlorine is from one-ton containers.  Two containers are connected to the water treatment evaporation system located in a raw water filter #57 building.  Up to eight

full containers are stored in a sheltered process area adjacent to the raw water filter building #57.  The maximum inventory is 20,000 lbs. included in process and storage containers.
The boundaries of the chlorine system subject to the RMP regulation include:  the eight each one-ton container in the storage area and the raw water filter building #57, which contains two one ton containers and all associated piping, vents and exhaust systems.  It also includes the service water pump building #56, feed and injection systems.
1.2.2.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE (b)(2)
Chlorine is the only regulated substance on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantities. 
1.3.    WORST AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS ( c)
The worst case and alternate scenarios were evaluated using both EPA guidance and air dispersion modeling.  An off-site consequence analysis is required by the RMP rule to estimate potential impacts to the community.  As required by RMP, S. D. Warren's off-site consequence analysis included evaluation of a worst case accidental release for chlorine and an alternative release for each covered chemical.

1.4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (d)
S. D. Warren's accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM program has been in place and effectively used for several years.  It is part of the standard operating procedure for the facility.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall site program.  The second is the chlorine specific actions within the site program.  These programs are coordinated with Muskegon Fire Department.
1.4.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (d)(1)
Facility-wide, elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  The basic elements are described below: 
1.4.1.1.    Employee Participation.  S. D. Warren has developed and implemented a written plan of action regarding employee participation in

ations, shutdown, startup, temporary and normal safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.  S. D. Warren confirms that employees and contractors involved in operating covered processes have successfully completed the required periodic training.  S. D. Warren documents that covered employees and contractors have received and understood the required RMP/PSM refresher training.  Documentation, at a minimum, includes the identity of the employee or contract employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.  These records are maintained by the Human Resources Department.
1.4.1.5.    Contractors.  As part of S. D. Warren's contractor selection process we obtain and evaluate information regarding contract employer's safety performance and programs per 29 C.F.R.  1910.119(h).  S. D. Warren also: 
A. Informs contract employers of the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the covered processes;
B. Explains to contract employers the applicable provisions of the facility's integrated contingency plan (discussed below); and
C. Controls the entrance, presence and exit of contract employers and contract employees in covered process areas.
1.4.1.6.    Pre-startup Safety Review:  As required, following installation of new and/ or modifications to a covered process, a pre-startup review is conducted.  This review ensures that the process is constructed and the equipment is designed in accordance with specifications; and that appropriate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place to adequately protect the health and safety of employees and the public.
1.4.1.7.    Hot Work Permit:  As part of its overall fire protection program, S. D. Warren implements a hot work permit program.  It covers all hot work operations (e.g., welding, soldering, etc.) conducted throughout the mill and on or near RMP covered processes.
1.4.1.8.    Managemen

t of Change:  S. D. Warren has established and implements a procedure to authorize and document changes in covered processes.  This procedure ensures all required considerations are addressed prior to any change to equipment, facilities, raw materials, and procedures being implemented.  This procedure also includes emergency change protocols.
1.4.1.9.    Incident Investigation.  S. D. Warren investigates each incident, which resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a significant release of a highly hazardous chemical in the workplace.  An incident investigation team is established and consists of:
1).  At least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, 
2).  Includes a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, 
3).  Other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. 
1.4.1.10.    Emergency Planning and Response.  S. D. Warren has developed an integrated contingency plan that satisfies all applicable state and federal emergency response and accidental prevention planning requirements (described under emergency response policies below). 
1.4.1.11.    Compliance Audits.  S. D. Warren has evaluated its compliance with OSHA's PSM and EPA RMP Standard in November 2000, in February 2001, and on August 21, 2003.  We also require an audit at least every three years to verify that the procedures and practices it has developed are adequate and are being followed.  S. D. Warren addresses all audit findings in a safe and timely manner.
1.4.1.12.    Trade Secrets.  S. D. Warren makes all necessary information available to those persons responsible for compiling process safety information and those assisting in the development of the process hazard analysis. 
1.4.2.    CHLORINE - SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (d)(2)
Chemical-specific prevention features at the facility include detailed procedures for the operation and maintenance of the chlorine system.

1.4.2.3.    Facility Design
The water treatment chlorine evaporation building is equipped with fan ventilation system, chlorine monitor and alarm.
1.4.2.4.    Equipment Design
The chlorine system is designed to meet the equipment design criteria of the Chlorine Institute. 
1.5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (e)
S. D. Warren has had no chlorine releases in the past five years.
1.6.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (f)
Emergency response procedures are contained in S. D. Warren's Emergency Response Plan (ERP). The ERP is coordinated with and reviewed by the Muskegon Fire Department, which coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and HazMat Team #3, Muskegon, Michigan.
1.6.1.    PERSONNEL (f)(1)
S. D. Warren has a dedicated Plant Protection Department that is responsible for all the above mill wide safety programs.  Plus, mill employees make up the operator, maintenance and emergency response teams. 
1.7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (g)
S. D. Warren discontinued the use of three processes that contain regulated substances.   The first process that was shut down, isolated and decomissioned in July, 2001, was the chlorine railcar and evaporation system.   This reduced the maximum quantity in a single vessel from 180,000 pounds to 2,000 pounds.  Based on preliminary off site impact studies, the radius to the endpoint was reduced from 14 to 2 miles which reduced the area by a factor of 50. The number of homes and facilities impacted has been drastically reduced.  The second process, also decommissioned in July, 2001, was the original chlorine dioxide generation facility.  This reduced the total chemical inventory of chlorine dioxide by 2,500 pounds. And recently the pulp mill and bleach plant were shutdown, eliminating the chlorine di
oxide plant in the process. S.D. Warren continually reviews implemented and potential safety improvements for all of its operations.

1.     EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 68.155
S. D. Warren Company operates a paper mill.  The mill is located at 2400 Lakeshore Drive, Muskegon, Michigan.  The Utility Department operates one process unit, which contains EPA listed highly hazardous chemicals over the regulated threshold.  Chlorine is used in the Utility Water Treatment Plant.

S.D. Warren continuously strives to improve its accident prevention, environmental protection, and emergency response programs.  Since 1980 we have developed many programs that eliminate or minimize the effects of an accidental release.  In 1992 the mill adopted the OSHA Process Management Program (PSM).  In 1999 the mill implemented the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP program).  In 2001 the mill installed and commissioned a new R-8, "state of the art", chlorine dioxide generation unit.  This permitted shutting down and decommissioning of two older RMP covered processes.  Both units had supplied the Pulp Mill Bleach Plant. The Pulp Mill Bleach Plant and associated R8 plant were shutdown on August 19, 2005. The remaining chlorine unit is the primary supply to the water treatment plant.  Removal of these three units reduced the worst case area and greatly reduced the potential impact. This has significantly improved the safety potential of the mill's operations.  All of this was accomplished in compliance with the RMP regulation.

S. D. Warren 's Risk Management Program complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's ("EPA's") Chemical Accident Prevention rule found in 40 C.F.R. Part 68.
